2 But it is to be noted, at the same time, that God does not make use of this heavier kind of punishment, except towards offenses especi- ally tending to his dishonour, as false worship, pei-jury, sacrilege. Nor did the Greeks judge otherwise3 for the crimes which were supposed to entail a curse on posterity‚ are all of this kind; as Plutarch learnedly shews in his book On the procrastinated anger of the gods. In Elian, we have an oracle which says that the guilty cannot escape, but that ven- geance follows them and their posterity. But there, sacrilege was in question, as is proved by the history of the Thelosan gold. We have above adduced similar opinions concerning pei-jury.
